reviewText: When Beavis and Butthead ran starting back in 1993 the shows were made up of two shorts and the guys commenting on music videos.  There was a very nasty law suit in that year against MTV and the show over an episode called "Comedians".  Two kids burned down a trailer home, and the show came under fire for the delinquent tendencies of the leads.  MTV severely edited the series, and those original cuts were lost.  Also Mike Judge was under EXTREME pressure to crank out 65 episodes a year, as the show aired several times a week.  There were some quality control issues with the animation, and frankly even Judge was not happy with some of the episodes.For them to release a whole season (especially that first one) would be too expensive.  You couldn't get the rights to all the videos they commented on without spending a fortune (the set would cost you hundreds of dollars as a result).  Also many early eps that were edited do not exist in their original form anymore.  So what Mike Judge and MTV did was pick the ones they liked the most from what they had.  There will be 3 volumes.  You get 11 videos with commentary from Beavis and Butthead, and 40 of the shorts.These may not be YOUR personal favorites, but you do get the debut of CORNHOLIO, and several very funny moments like when the two are sent all the way back to kindergarden.  About 23 of the episodes include sequences never before broadcast!  So you get them unedited and in extended forms.  This is a great set!  Don't let the approach fool you.  This is the best way for them to release the show, the most cost effective way, and also the way to insure you get the best of the show.
summary: Here's why we don't get the seasons... and why it's Volume One

reviewText: There is not much of a reason to do so. There is no story arch, no character development other than perhaps Beavis channeling Cornholio, and not enough cultural references to date any of the episodes. You could easily air a  season seven episode followed by a third season episode with no problem. It is not like putting M.A.S.H. on DVD where characters were written out when their actors left the series while new ones where written in. Showing an episode with Col. Potter followed by one with Col. Blake would not make much sense.So why should they release Beavis & Butt-head in season box sets? Because that is the only way the buyer can be sure that they will get every episode.Remembering back to the days of VHS and Laserdisc, whenever a series of any kind was released, it was usually done with two episodes a tape/disc. They would usually take the most popular episode of the entire series and pair it with a more obscure episode for the first volume, and keep this up for the next ten to fifteen volumes, pairing popular episodes with obscure. However, once they ran out of the popular episodes they would usually abandon the series. Another problem was movie shorts such as "Laurel & Hardy" and "The Three Stooges" as well as cartoon's such as the Warner Brothers Cartoons. I don't know how many times the Warner Brothers "Loony tunes" cartoons were released in volumes only to be abandoned after a couple of years. Even the Laserdisc collections fell far short of complete.Releasing a series in chronological order guarantees that nothing is skipped. And if for some reason the volumes are abandoned after a few years are released then the series could always be picked up where last left off when there is another round of volumes released. That is something that is not done when the last few volumes were best of compilations.I would like to take the time here to dispense with some myths about the Beavis & Butt-head series on DVD. One is that they do not or cannot have the video commentary segments that were once part of the cartoon because it would be too expensive. This is nonsense. If that were the case then how are secondary DVD labels able to release music video collections? For about $15 you get 15 - 20 full videos. Here MTV is only showing partial videos, and they own the rest of the content. If the record labels were charging full royalties for each video then that would only be about an extra $30 a DVD, and since MTV does not have to pay royalties to themselves to put their own cartoon on DVD then they could easily release a season box at $50. However, more likely the record labels would be willing to give MTV a break and charge 1/4 the royalties as usually the videos were cut off before the chorus or edited short. That would be about $8 extra a season. MTV could easily offset the cost anyway by having the full uncut videos as bonus material on the DVD's.The other myth is that the banned episodes no longer exist or only now exist as edited versions. I really doubt that the MTV executives would be so stupid as to take their master copies of the completed episodes and edit those. Usually the way it works is that after the master copy is completed, copies are dubbed from that to actually air on MTV, thus protecting the master from wearing out from repeated airplay. They would have had several dub copies to edit from. But even if they did edit the finished master and somehow threw out all their copies of the original version, the separate elements would still exist and they could easily reedit a new master from the source material. And I am also sure that the animating company as well as Mike Judge owns their own master copies of the series.Basically what is happening here is this... Some MTV executive with a bug up his ass does not want the episodes that he had banned to reappear on any of their home video releases. Nor does he want to pay for the videos no matter what they cost. As long as people keep buying incomplete versions of the cartoon series those episodes will never be released. But if the DVD tanks and the main reason is that the fans are waiting for a complete season by season release then those episodes will finally be included.Either way, unless this volume just happens to have all the Beavis & Butt-head episodes you give a damn about then I would not bother buying it. Nor would I expect that the later volumes [ if any, are released ] would even come close to completing the series.
summary: Do you really need to release Beavis & Butt-head in season box sets?

reviewText: I always liked "Beavis & Butt-Head", but I hated the notion that it was the beginning of the end for MTV, in terms of actually playing music videos, anyway. The success of "B&B" led the channel to run more original programming, and less and less of what the channel actually started out as 1981. Anyway, "Beavis & Butt-Head, Volume 1: The Mike Judge Collection" is a worthy addition to your DVD collection if you enjoyed the series in the 1990's. There are 40 episodes, and thankfully, they are not interrupted by music video clips (I liked music videos, but not during "B&B"). The standout episode is, without debate, "The Great Cornholio", found on Disc Two. If you remember anything about the series, it was that episode, when Beavis overdoses on sugar and caffeine, pulls his Metallica T-shirt over his head and proclaims " I AM THE GREAT CORNHOLIO! I NEED T.P. FOR MY BUNGHOLE!!" How creator Mike Judge came up with that episode is explained briefly on Disc Three's "Taint Of Greatness" segment. While I am disappointed to a degree that other episodes I remember are not on this collection ("Wood Shop", where Beavis saws off his finger, has it re-attached and then breaks it off while picking his nose, I miss greatly), I am hopeful they'll appear on Volume 2, which is slated for release this year. Overall, it's nice to have the boys back, and this collection, while not perfect, is a good addition to your DVD library if you enjoyed the mis-adventures of Beavis & Butt-Head.
summary: Decent Collection For The Casual B&B Viewer

reviewText: The slapstick animation series that once aired on MTV under the name Beavis & Butt-head has been called many different things.  Some critics characterized it as the personification of stupidity and corrupt amidst a growing entertainment industry while others hailed its rebellious social criticism.  Despite the fiery criticism the show went on for a period of five years and to the making of a feature film, which was a big financial success.  In volume one, the audience can experience 40 different episodes such as 1-900-BEAVIS, Manners Suck, and the priceless The Great Cornholio.  All episodes intentionally offend and irate the audience through the dim-witted Beavis and brainless Butt-head that are both voiced by its creator Mike Judge who now is also known for Office Space (1999).It is within its own stupidity an amusing caricature of two teens in suburbia emerges, as apathy and self-destruction seems to overwhelm their existence.  Nonetheless, there are a few things that trigger some life in their seemingly hollow existence such as foul language, glue sniffing, and rock-n-roll.  They also desire women, but their carnal longing for the opposite sex is a fruitless affair.  The combination of their high testosterone and their sexual desire overflows into a Freudian obsession with words of sexual nature to which they continue to snicker and chuckle in an eternity.Through these two misfits several social issues surface such as education, teen sexuality, and other adolescent issues.  Many of them are blatantly presented without tact and consideration for the audience, as it purposely intends to shock and awe.  It is within the outrageous provocation that Mike Judge succeeds in generating a dialogue, or maybe, more of an outcry for a ban of Beavis and Butt-head.  Nonetheless, the Beavis and Butt-head show spread like wildfire, and it gained a rapidly growing number of dedicated supporters that opposed some fraction of the American society, as the youth could relate to the issues of the idiots Beavis and Butt-head.Beavis & Butt-head, Vol. 1 - The Mike Judge Collection is worth a viewing for nostalgia and laughter, as the two dense characters Beavis and Butt-head face everyday issues.  It is not as funny as many might have remembered it for the first time, but it still induces some laughter and reminiscence.  Personally, I only see this as a rental, but there might be many out there who disagree.

reviewText: I can't tell you how ecstatic I was when I heard there would be a Beavis and Butthead DVD collection coming out. For people today who didn't grow up watching this show, it's hard to understand why fans like myself love this show so much. To most people Beavis and Butthead is a stupid show, about two stupid kids, doing stupid things, and using bad languege. But to kids who grew up in the 90's and fans this show is golden because it was so creative. Beavis and Butthead opened a lot of doors for cartoons to come afterwards, and the animated world would not have ever been the same if these two foul-mouthed, fart joke telling teenagers had never graced our tvs. Unfortunately when I finally got a hold of this box seat, I was more than dissapointed. Once again MTV has continued to shaft die hard B&B; fans by not releasing seasonal box sets, but instead "greatest episodes" knock offs, which is more or less what this is. The episodes were picked by series creator Mike Judge, and although there are some great episodes on here, this DVD set lacks a lot of the episodes and elements of the tv show which made it so great. Die hard fans should beware.First of all you get 40 episodes on this set, some of which have never been released on a DVD before. This is good because you now have a lot of classic B&B; episodes at your fingertips that you can watch whenever you please. Some of my personal favorite episodes like "Beavis And Butthead Vs. The Vending Machine" and "Tainted Meat" appear on this collection which is nice. The overall selection of episodes is not bad, and you somewhat come see how much the show evolved from the earlier days of episodes like "Home Improvement", to episodes like "The Pipe Of Doom." You get a varied array of episodes from every season which is good since some of the episodes are hardly aired on television anymore. The third disc is a lot of behind the scenes exclusives and interviews, which is a great treat if you are more than the average B&B; fan. There's also a documentary featuring Mike Judge on how he created to abomination known as Beavis and Butthead.Unfortunately this set has more than its fair share of problems. First just like the Timelife Beavis and Butthead collections, there's no music videos present in the episodes. This really hurts the show, because one of the most memorable aspects of watching Beavis And Butthead was listening to them trash or praise the music that most of us grew up listening to. The actual episodes themselves are also too short to stand alone by themselves, which makes most of the DVD seem like it flies by. There are 10 video critics on the DVD, but they feel tacked on, and just a way to satisfy fans who wanted them. However they aren't found within the episodes, so why bother even watching them? Considering MTV was responsible for this show, it's hard to understand why they wouldn't even at least make the effort to try to get the licenses of the videos so they could put them on the DVDs. I'm sure it wouldn't be any harder than it was to have them on the actual show when it was airing on television. The other main problem with this DVD set is the fact that the episodes are "Director's Cuts". At first I was happy, hoping that some episodes which had originally been too controversial for tv would be found in their entirety on this set. While some episodes have slightly added material, some have been extremely neutered. The most notable episode is "Late Night With Butthead", where Butthead gets the idea to have his own late night talk show. Pretty much all of the intro of the show where Butthead is inspired to have his own late night talk show has been deleted. There's also other significant portions of this episode which have been removed for no apparent reason. There are other episodes which have been altered as well, and if you would like to know which and where, there is a spotlight review at the top which tells exactly what's been altered.In addition to these problems, there's also a lack of fan favorite episodes. Like another reviewer said, just because they're Mike Judge's favorite episodes, doesn't mean they're mine. I have to wonder how seminal episodes like "The Great Cornholio", and "Vaya Con Cornholio", one of B&B;'s most famous trademarks were left out. Also other episodes that were among fan favorites like "Butt-o-ween" and "Beavis and Butthead's Island" are mysteriously absent. This is very discouraging. The fact that this DVD set has "VOL 1" plastered on it, isn't any reassuring, because it makes it seem like there are more bad box sets on the way. Why can't MTV just wise up and give us what we want?Overall this box set isn't very essential to anyone, even if you are a die hard Beavis and Butthead fan. The fact that MTV continues to slap fans in the face by not releasing seasonal box sets is just appalling. Sure you're getting some great episodes and nice behind the scenes footage here, but without the music videos and crude jokes that made this show so great in the first place, it's not worth the money. We can only hope that MTV will eventually come around and give us seasonal box sets like we all want. Comedy Central is now airing B&B; every week day at 7:00 PM, so I would recommend just watching that instead of buying this box set. You'll probably see every episodes found on this set on tv at one point or another. If you must buy B&B; on DVD, I'd say just get the Timelife collections instead. They have the episodes in their entirety (although once again without the music videos), and more or less you're getting the exact same thing as this set without the extras. Nothing left to say. Biggest DVD disappointment I've ever purchased...
summary: A Huge Disappointment, Approach With Caution

reviewText: When Beavis & Butthead first hit the airwaves, many tried to dismiss it as mere stupid moronic nonsense that would appeal to the  teen-age set. I was not a teen-ager at the time, but I recognized it immediately as the most realistic portrait of American culture that was ever aired on TV. The portrayal of the moronic hi-jinks of two morons doesn't make a program either stupid or moronic.The surprise of the whole deal was that it was aired on MTV, for MTV was realistically and unflatteringly portraying the vast bulk of their viewing audience. It was and is the only worthwhile thing MTV has ever aired. It is the only thing on MTV I've ever bothered to watch.I came upon it accidently during the very early days of its airing and, luckily, started taping the episodes almost immediately, recognizing it for what it was--an autobiography of our times more honest than anyone was willing to admit. Thus I got most of the episodes before the show became wildly popular, before big shots began noticing it and before the demand for the censorship of its contents began. Thus I got, and still have, the most subversive episodes of this show as they were originally aired.Which brings us to this DVD release of the show. Naturally MTV, one of the most worthless enterprises in human history, screwed the whole deal up. I haven't, and likely won't, buy the set, so I haven't seen it. But judging from the reviews here, it is obvious that MTV hasn't the guts to release these cartoons in their original form because the honesty of the cartoons would frighten any organization so prostrated before the fascistic gods of political correctness.It also seems obvious that the creator of the characters, Mike Judge, is embarrassed by the creations that made his fame and wealth. This is too bad but shouldn't be entirely unexpected. As he started out with B&B;, he was likely a poor unknown, doing with his cartoons what he wanted to, making them to tickle his own fancy and making his characters do what he thought was funny and  would amuse him. Once he became rich and famous, most likely his social group changed, he began moving with more "important" people, and the peer pressure from this group likely led him to feel shame for his former honesty. Thus in re-releasing his creations, he excised the parts of them which were offensive to his new group of peers. The self-censorship brought on by thefear of insulting or offending "friends" is one of the most destructive forces facing a creative artist, and most of them cannot overcome it once they have reached a stage of comfort and security they are not willing to risk or lose.Even with all this, with the censorship and with the stupidity of issuing this set as a "selection" rather than as a complete series, I likely would have bought this set anyway, hoping a good sale would lead to further, more complete releases. What I find intolerable is the idea that a set you BUY would include a FIVE minute commercial which you COULD NOT skip at the beginning of a disc and would be forced to watch every time you wanted to watch that disk. And that THAT commercial would be a promotion of some other MTV release, which will doubtlessly be beyond my ability to endure.There is no way I will be allow myself to be FORCED into any such indignity. This is not Soviet Russia nor Nazi Germany. I will not be forced into watching what is intolerable to me. If MTV, in their arrogance, put it up to a question of "YOU WILL WATCH WHAT WE WANT YOU TO WATCH OR YOU WILL NOT SEE WHAT YOU WANT TO SEE", I will not buy their product. For all their obvious admiration of police state tactics, I don't believe that these media fascists have the power to send me to a GULAG or Dachau--at least not yet.I still have my old Beavis & Butthead tapes and will stick to them until there is a release of this series which treats its fans with the respect our 25-35 dollars deserves.If there was ever justification for supporting illegal copying or bootlegging of copywrighted material, this MTV release is it.

My favorite is the video where Butthead tells Beavis to go prepare some pancakes for them while he (Butthead) sits and watches the videos.  The back-and-forth exchange between the two as Beavis asks Butthead how pancakes are prepared is hilarious!  Despite that I happily own this set, I still videotape B and B on MTV on weeknights.  So I can still enjoy the music videos and B and B's commentary whenever I want to see them.Perhaps this little tip may help some of the irate owners of this new Beavis and Butthead dvd set to cope with the lack of music videos in-between the cartoons (although I may end up getting snide comments for it!). The film was still funny, and most of us loved it!  So, at least there are some of the music videos available in this dvd set for us to enjoy.  Who knows?  Perhaps Mike Judge may be able to get the copyrights of a few more videos when he brings out Volume 2 of the Beavis and Butthead dvd set.  We'll just have to wait and see.I understand devout B and B fans want Season box sets of the series, and I hope they get their wish granted.  But in the meantime, this dvd set is just fine for me.  I wasn't interested in B and B when Time-Life videos first produced their dvd set.  Now, I enjoy - and love - Beavis and Butthead, and I'm glad this new dvd set came out, enabling me to get my own copy.  Plus the extras on Disc 3, such as their television 'appearances' on the MTV music awards, with David Letterman, and with Kurt Loder on the Thanksgiving Day special, and other clips and promos with B and B are pretty neat gems to have on disc!In regard to those annoying MTV ads of non-Beavis and Butthead material on the discs, I simply cue them off using the >> button on my dvd remote control.
